interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness
Review Date: 2013/10/16
Store: Rachel Dratch  (Actor),     Hillel Halkin  (Actor),     Joseph Dorman  (Director)    &                   0                  more   Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Documentary
Product Description: ['Product Description', 'A riveting portrait of the great writer whose stories became the basis of the Broadway musical Fiddler on the Roof, SHOLEM ALEICHEM: LAUGHING IN THE DARKNESS tells the tale of the rebellious genius who created an entirely new literature. Plumbing the depths of a Jewish world locked in crisis and on the cusp of profound change, he captured that world with brilliant humor. Sholem Aleichem was not just a witness to the creation of a new modern Jewish identity, but one of the very men who forged it.', 'Special Features', 'Making the Film; On Sholem Aleichem', 'Making the Film; On Sholem Aleichem', 'Review', '100% Fresh --Rotten Tomatoes…a rich, beautifully organized and illustrated modern history. --New York Times Critics PickCompelling…A beautifully made documentary that sets the record straight in a thoughtful, incisive way. --Los Angeles Times', 'About the Actor', "Rachel Dratch grew up in Lexington, Massachusetts. After graduating from Dartmouth College with a degree in Drama and Psychology, she moved out to Chicago, where she studied with Del Close at Improvolympic. She was on the house team, Victim's Family, with Adam McKay. Rachel went on to tour with the Second City Touring Company and eventually advanced to the Second City Mainstage, where she appeared in four revues: Pinata Full Of Bees, Citizen Gates, Paradigm Lost and Promisekeepers Losers Weepers. For the latter two, she received the Joseph Jefferson Award for Best Actress in a Revue. After leaving the mainstage, she wrote and performed in the 2-person sketch show, Dratch and Fey, with Tina Fey. The show was seen at Second City, Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in NYC, and the Aspen Comedy Festival. In the fall of 1999, Rachel joined the cast of Saturday Night Live (1975), where she performed for 7 years. Her memorable characters include Boston teen Denise, the Lovers professors with Will Ferrell, junior high school student Sheldon and Debbie Downer.", 'Hillel Halkin (born 1939) is an American-born Israeli translator, biographer, literary critic, and novelist. He was born in New York two months before the outbreak of World War II. He is the son of Abraham S. Halkin, a professor of Jewish literature, history and culture at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. In 1970 he made aliyah to Israel, settling in Zichron Yaakov. He studied English Literature at Columbia University. Halkin is married to Marcia and the father of two daughters.', "Jason Kravits (born May 28, 1967) is an American actor. His film credits include The Stepford Wives and Sweet November. Kravits has served more often as a television guest star. He can be seen in episodes of shows such as Friends; Law & Order: Special Victims Unit; Everybody Loves Raymond;Yes, Dear; Gilmore Girls; Law & Order and Harry's Law. He also performed in the Broadway show The Drowsy Chaperone with his brother Garth Kravits and in Relatively Speaking. He got his start playing Lolo Knopke on the short-lived 1982 PBS series PowerhouseHe played the District Attorney Richard Bay in the Emmy Award-Winning drama Series The Practice from 1999 to 2001. After almost three years of being a nemesis to the firm who would stop at nothing to get a conviction, his character was gunned down by associates of a man he successfully prosecuted. In 2000, he was a regular panelist on the Oxygen Network revival of I've Got a Secret. In the early 1990s, he was a company member at Round House Theatre in Silver Spring, Maryland. He was also a counselor at Green Acres Camp in Rockville, Maryland, where he played guitar and performed skits for campers. In 1986, he founded the University of Maryland's first improv theater group Erasable Inc. He attended Colonel Zadok A. Magruder High School.", 'About the Director', 'Joseph Dorman, born April 23rd, 1958, grew up in the Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills. Graduated from high school in 1976 from Cranbrook School, Bloomfield Hills, Michigan. Studied at Brown University, Providence, RI, from where he graduated in 1980. Taught briefly at a prep school in Westchester County, NY before focusing on film as a career. Lives in New York City.', 'See more']
Average Rating: 4.8
Product Details: {'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 0.7 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Director': 'Joseph Dorman', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, NTSC, Black & White', 'Run time': '1 hour and 33 minutes', 'Release date': 'March 12, 2013', 'Actors': 'Rachel Dratch, Hillel Halkin, Jason Kravits', 'Studio': 'Docurama', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: I have gotten a new found admiration for the life and times of this man.He has gone through a hell on earth and maintained his connection to his life as a jew. He triuphed in his works.
Review Title: superb
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
5 Broken Cameras
Emad Burnat  (Actor, Director),     Guy Davidi  (Director)    Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Documentary
['Product Description', 'An extraordinary work of both cinematic and political activism, 5 Broken Cameras is a deeply personal, first-hand account of non-violent resistance in Bil\'in, a West Bank village threatened by encroaching Israeli settlements. Shot almost entirely by Palestinian farmer Emad Burnat, who bought his first camera in 2005 to record the birth of his youngest son, the footage was later turned into a galvanizing cinematic experience by co-directors Guy Davidi and Burnat. Structured around the violent destruction of a succession of Burnat\'s video cameras, the filmmakers\' collaboration follows one family\'s evolution over five years of village turmoil. Burnat watches from behind the lens as olive trees are bulldozed, protests intensify, and lives are lost. "I feel like the camera protects me," he says, "but it\'s an illusion".', 'Review', 'A rigorous and moving work of art. --A.O. Scott, The New York TimesUniquely powerful, putting faces and human consequences to a political dispute that will seemingly never end. --The Hollywood Reporter']
{'Genre': 'Special Interests', 'Format': 'Subtitled, Anamorphic, Multiple Formats, Dolby, Color, Surround Sound, Dubbed, NTSC, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Guy Davidi, Emad Burnat', 'Language': 'Hebrew', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 30 minutes', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': '26172163', 'Director': 'Emad Burnat, Guy Davidi', 'Media Format': 'Subtitled, Anamorphic, Multiple Formats, Dolby, Color, Surround Sound, Dubbed, NTSC, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 30 minutes', 'Release date': 'January 15, 2013', 'Actors': 'Emad Burnat', 'Dubbed': 'Arabic', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'Kino Lorber films', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
I think the issue of the Israeli occupation was a bit one sided from the biased point of view of the Palastinians. I suppose it could have gone both ways.
My opinion
A Yiddish World Remembered
Elliott Gould  (Actor),     Andrew Goldberg  (Director, Producer)    Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Documentary
['Elliott Gould narrates this Emmy Award winning documentary which revisits the beautiful Eastern European Jewish world before the horrifying aftermath of World War II. Using rare archival films, vintage photos, personal recollections, traditional cantorial and more, it becomes an emotional portrayal of Jewish traditions, religious treasures, the fascinating language of Yiddish and life as it was. 2002/color-b&w/100 min/NR/fullscreen.']
{'Genre': 'Special Interests', 'Format': 'NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Andrew Goldberg, Elliott Gould', 'Language': 'Unqualified', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 40 minutes', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Item model number': 'unknown', 'Director': 'Andrew Goldberg', 'Media Format': 'NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 40 minutes', 'Release date': 'April 20, 2010', 'Actors': 'Elliott Gould', 'Producers': 'Andrew Goldberg', 'Studio': 'Shanchie Records', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
I enjoyed the film. It covers a lot of what I heard of the old country by my parents and grandparents
lots of good footage
The World of Sholom Aleichem
Zero Mostel  (Actor),     Nancy Walker  (Actor)    Rated:    Unrated    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, TV
["A compilation of three stories from Sholom Aleichem (known as the Yiddish Mark Twain) – “A Tale of Chelm,” about a bookseller who tries to buy a goat in a town of fools; “Bontche Schweig,” a tale of a poor man whose heavenly arrival coaxes tears from the angels; and “The High School,” about a couple's attempts to send their son to a non-religious school. Starring Zero Mostel, Nancy Walker and Sam Levene."]
{'Genre': 'TV', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, Full Screen, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Jack Gilford, Nancy Walker, Zero Mostel, Sam Levene, Lee Grant', 'Language': 'English', 'Number Of Discs': '1', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.33:1', 'MPAA rating': 'Unrated (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.5 x 0.7 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, Full Screen, NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 41 minutes', 'Release date': 'July 1, 2016', 'Actors': 'Zero Mostel, Nancy Walker, Sam Levene, Jack Gilford, Lee Grant', 'Studio': 'Entertainment One', 'Number of discs': '1'}
I learned so much from this film about the origins of yiddish theater of which I'm a big fan. It described his work to a great extent.
I really was facinated

profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

The user maintains a strong interest in documentary films addressing political and social issues, particularly those incorporating personal narratives and storytelling. Their recent exploration into Jewish cultural expressions, including Yiddish theater, highlights their appreciation for historical contexts and the arts, fostering a deeper understanding of complex human experiences and traditions.

An evident enthusiasm for historical figures, as demonstrated in their latest viewing, reveals an admiration for narratives that intertwine humor and crises within cultural identities. They are drawn to documentaries that feature firsthand accounts and archival materials while promoting thoughtful activism about global conflicts, including sensitive topics like the Israeli-Palestinian situation. 

The user values balanced portrayals in political narratives, demonstrating a critical lens regarding bias and a preference for works that challenge perceptions and inspire introspection about contemporary issues. Their engagement with cinema is characterized by a desire for thought-provoking content that combines emotional depth with historical insight, reflecting a commitment to exploring diverse perspectives and artistic expressions.

Overall, the consistent pattern in their viewing habits emphasizes an analytical approach to both historical and contemporary narratives, resonating with personal and communal identities while navigating intricate societal themes.
